article_title: The Beginning of the Arab Conquests in North Africa

paragraphs.text: The Arab conquests, a significant historical phenomenon, began in the 7th century and led to the formation of a vast empire . This expansion followed the rise of the Prophet Muhammad and the unification of Arabia under Islam . The conquests were not solely religious in nature, although religion played a crucial role . The rise of the Prophet and the existing balance of power between empires influenced the Arab conquests . The traditional date for the death of Prophet Muhammad is 632 CE . Some scholars propose that the conquests began before this date, based on non-Muslim sources .

The early Arab conquests, spanning from 622 A.D. to 656 A.D., involved mobility as a key factor . The camel and horse were crucial for transportation and warfare . The conquests transformed the Old World, incorporating former Roman provinces in North Africa into the new Islamic world .

The Arab conquest of northwest Africa is a major event in North African Studies . The Arab conquest occurred in stages, beginning in the 640s . The decisive capture of Egypt in the early 640s laid the foundations for the Arab conquest of North Africa . In 642 and 643, the conquest of Cyrenaica and Tripolitania took place . ‘Amr ibn al-‘As, before leading the troops that conquered Egypt, had traded in Egypt and Ethiopia before the Hijra (622) . He founded the first mosque in Africa in Fustat in 641 . The Byzantines evacuated Alexandria in 642 .

Key leaders in the Arab conquest of al-Maghrib included Muawiya b. Hudayj, Uqbah ibn Nafi, Hassan ibn al-Numan, and Musa ibn Nusayr . The conquest began during the reign of Umar ibn al-Khattab (634-644) . Muawiya b. Hudayj was sent to Ifriqiya in 665 . Uqbah ibn Nafi built the city of Kairouan (al-Qayrawān) in Ifrīqiyā between 670 and 675 . The garrison town of al-Qayrawān, established in 670, became the capital of Arab presence in the west .

The Arab conquest of the Maghreb was resumed from Egypt . In 688, Kairouan was retaken, and in 695, Carthage was conquered . Between 695 and 700, the Berbers of the Aurès, led by the Kahina, led a strong resistance to the Arab conquest . The Arab conquest of northwest Africa led to the Islamization and Arabization of the Berber populations . Historians debate the chronology, character, and extent of the Islamization and Arabization processes .

The Berbers of North Africa converted to Islam in large numbers soon after their conquest by the Arabs in the second half of the seventh century . However, there is a lack of reliable evidence regarding the conversion process . The Berbers became protagonists in Islamic history, often as dissident Muslims of the Kharijite persuasion . The Maghrib saw revolts in the 740s involving Berbers and Kharijism .

Musa ibn Nusayr, Governor of Kairouan, completed the conquest of the Maghreb, opening the door to the conquest of Spain in 711 . In 711, Ṭāriq b. Ziyād crossed the Mediterranean into Iberia with an army predominantly composed of northwest Africans . The Muslims who entered Iberia in 711 were mainly Berbers . Ṭāriq b. Ziyād was a Berber . The event is the 'conquest of Spain', a part of the wider Islamic expansion from the Middle East into North Africa and beyond . The conquest began in 711 with the crossing of the Strait of Gibraltar by a mostly Berber force led by Ṭāriq ibn Ziyād . Mūsā ibn Nuṣayr was the governor of Ifrīqiya (modern-day Tunisia) and played a key role in the conquest .

The Umayyads (661-750) made the Maghrib a single province (wilāya) . In the west, the Arab elite put in place a system of precedence that guaranteed them preferential treatment . In 739 and 740, rebellions from al-Qayrawān to Tangier seriously threatened Umayyad rule in the region . In al-Andalus, a similar rebellion in 741-2 showed that disunity among Arabs could seriously challenge the status quo . When the ʿAbbāsids and their supporters in the east put an end to Umayyad rule in 750, al-Qayrawān hailed the new rulers .

The Umayyad Caliphate, particularly under Mu'awiya, focused on consolidating power while simultaneously paying attention to the conquests . The study period covers 41 to 91 AH/661 to 710 . All territories of al-Maghrib, except Ceuta, were captured during the Umayyad era .

The Arabs began a process of “Berberization” of northwest Africa, its peoples, and their pasts . Medieval Arabic sources agree that the Arab conquests also involved the enslavement of a great number of northwest Africans . The preferred nisba for slaves from the Maghrib was “al-Barbarī” .

Malta's transition to Islam occurred in 870 . The period of clear Arab sovereignty in Malta is considered to be from 870 to 1091 . The text analyzes the transition using Byzantine and Arab sources . North African coasts were heavily fortified in the early 9th century . Arab raids on Sicily occurred before 827 . In 827, Euphemios, the Byzantine governor of Sicily, sought help from Ifriqiya . Ziyadat Allah, Emir of Ifriqiya, sent a force of 10,000 and 700 cavalry in 100 keels to Sicily . Malta was taken in 257 AH (870-871) according to Ibn al-Khaldun . The date of definitive capture is recorded in the Chronicle of Cambridge as August 29, 870 .

The Islamic conquest was closely linked to the spread of Arabic . The Berbers' adoption of Islam and their need to learn Arabic for understanding religious teachings were key factors . Arab migrations to the Maghreb facilitated the spread and development of Arabic . Mosques and kuttabs built alongside the conquests played a role . The Islamic conquest of the Maghreb was the beginning of a new Islamic culture that spread with the language of the Quran .

Arab conquests in North Africa began in 647-648 . The Arab conquests left a lasting impact on the culture of the region (Berberie) . Arabic replaced Berber languages in a large part of the Maghreb . Arabic was also influenced by Berber and Punic languages .

The book "Late Antique Responses to the Arab Conquests" examines the impact of the Arab conquests on various regions and cultures . It explores the historical context, offering insights into the social, cultural, and political transformations during the early Islamic period and the reactions of different groups and communities to the Arab conquests . The book shows how the Arab conquests changed both the Arabian conquerors and the conquered .

Maximus the Confessor's life and works intersected with the events surrounding the Arab conquests, particularly focusing on their impact on the Byzantine Empire and North Africa . Epistle 14, written between 634–640, references the Arab conquests and attributes them to Christian iniquities .

The Kharijite doctrine made a major entrance into the history of the Maghreb with the revolt of 740-742 against Arab governors . In the mid-8th century, a double movement of decomposition and autonomy affected the westernmost conquests of Islam . In 808, the Idrissids founded Fes . In 909, a Shiite adventurer proclaimed himself Caliph and seized Kairouan . The Fatimid caliphs founded Mahdiyya . In the 11th century, Arab tribes started to migrate westwards .
